column19: The learning curve for a stats program will take time so I am concerned that I may not learn everything I need to know by the end of the semester   I understand that I cannot learn EVERYTHING but I was hoping to get a very good basic understanding of both R and Unix I also want to have a solid understanding of what stats to use when, how stats can be manipulated, what is a "good" stat vs "bad" stat, etc
column20: I am most interested in learning R stats (for sure!) and Unix, but I would also like to know more about stats in general (when to use what test, why, how does it normalize data, etc) I feel like my undergraduate courses have said "Use this stat test" without giving me a good understanding of WHY (why use this test over another test?)   Also, I am a somewhat familiar with JMP (I used it in a summer internship) but I would also be interested in learning more about that program

column19: I don't feel confident in using statistics to analyze data
column20: I would like to be able to utilize statistics and computer power in understanding and presenting experimental data

column19: Nothing, I am excited to get started!

I am less apprehensive than last time
